title: German submarine U-523
text:
German submarine "U-523" was a <a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXC">Type IXC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. The submarine was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 4 August 1941 at the <a href="Deutsche%20Werft">Deutsche Werft</a> yard in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> as yard number 338. She was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 15 April 1942, and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 25 June under the command of "<a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a>" Werner Pietzsch. After training with the <a href="4th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">4th U-boat Flotilla</a> in the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, the U-boat was transferred to the <a href="10th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">10th flotilla</a> for front-line service on 1 February 1943.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXC">German Type IXC submarines</a> were slightly larger than the original <a href="German%20Type%20IXB%20submarine">Type IXB</a>s. "U-523" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. The U-boat had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="MAN%20SE">MAN</a> M 9 V 40/46 <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> four-stroke, nine-cylinder <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">Siemens-Schuckert</a> 2 GU 345/34 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-523" was fitted with six <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and two at the stern), 22 <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="10.5%20cm%20SK%20C/32%20naval%20gun">SK C/32 naval gun</a>, 180 rounds, and a <a href="3.7%20cm%20SK%20C/30">SK C/30</a> as well as a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of forty-eight.
Service history.
First patrol.
"U-523" departed <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> on 9 February 1943 and sailed out into the mid-Atlantic. On the morning of 19 March the 5,848 ton American merchant ship SS "Mathew Luckenbach", part of <a href="Convoys%20HX%20229/SC%20122">Convoy HX 229</a> en route to the <a href="United%20Kingdom">UK</a> from <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, was hit by two torpedoes fired by . The crew of eight officers, 34 crewmen and 26 <a href="United%20States%20Navy%20Armed%20Guard">armed guards</a> (the ship was armed with one gun, one gun, and eight <a href="Oerlikon%2020%20mm%20cannon">20 mm guns</a>) abandoned ship in three lifeboats and two rafts, and were picked up later by . Around 20:00 that evening, "U-523" discovered the drifting wreck of the "Mathew Luckenbach" and hit her with a single torpedo, sinking the ship within seven minutes. The U-boat arrived at her new home port of <a href="Lorient">Lorient</a>, in occupied France, on 16 April 1943 after 67 days at sea.
Second patrol.
"U-523" sailed from Lorient on 22 May 1943, but on the 24th, still in the <a href="Bay%20of%20Biscay">Bay of Biscay</a>, she was bombed by a British <a href="Armstrong%20Whitworth%20Whitley">Whitley</a> <a href="medium%20bomber">medium bomber</a> of <a href="No.%2010%20Squadron%20RAF">No. 10 Squadron RAF</a>. The U-boat was severely damaged and was forced to return to Lorient.
Third and fourth patrols.
"U-523" sailed from Lorient briefly on 1 August 1943, for a voyage lasting only three days, before setting out once more on 16 August, and headed south-west.
The U-boat was sunk on 25 August, west of <a href="Vigo">Vigo</a>, Spain, in position , by <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a>s from the <a href="V%20and%20W-class%20destroyer">destroyer</a> and the <a href="Flower-class%20corvette">corvette</a> . Seventeen of "U-523"s crew were killed and 37 survived the attack.
Wolfpacks.
"U-523" took part in four <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>s, namely.
